channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Federer wins ATP Tour Finals thriller
item.description: A day after clinching the year-end No. 1 spot for the third time, Novak Djokovic moved closer to another significant milestone at the World Tour Finals.

item.title: Raniero sacked after Faroes loss
item.description: Claudio Ranieri paid the price for Greece's humiliating defeat to the Faroe Islands when it was confirmed Saturday that he had been sacked as national team coach.

item.title: 100-cap Rooney lifts England
item.description: Wayne Rooney celebrated his 100th cap for England by scoring the equalizer in a 3-1 victory over Slovenia in an Euro 2016 qualifier at Wembley Saturday.

item.title: Misfiring Germany wins poorly
item.description: It was the first win in three Euro 2016 qualifying games for the mighty Die Mannschaft but another unconvincing performance by Germany against the minnows of Gibraltar Friday.

item.title: Bobsled gender barrier broken
item.description: If Elana Meyers Taylor makes bobsled history this season, her husband will have been the driving force.

item.title: Is Russia planning a winter offensive?
item.description: Russian forces are massing near Ukraine. Is it another signal that Moscow is taking a confrontational stance with the West and has no interest in reconciliation?

item.title: Global wealth gap is 'obscene'
item.description: Leaders meeting in the land of the "fair go" must tackle inequality, says Australian advocate.

item.title: Why we can't stop pushing into space
item.description: Gene Seymour despite our love-hate relationship with the excitement and cost of space travel--as in landing on a comet--it's part of our pioneering makeup to keep exploring the universe

item.title: The big lesson from comet landing
item.description: Rosetta mission shows we can do marvelous things if we work together, says astronomer,

item.title: Mexico outrage isn't going away
item.description: Jose Carre√±o Figueras says the cascade of scandals has produced a crisis of confidence among Mexicans

item.title: Peter Kassig 'beheaded' in video attributed to ISIS
item.description: The terror group ISIS claims to have beheaded hostage Peter Kassig -- an aid worker and former U.S. soldier -- in a video posted online Sunday.

item.title: Gerges: Video 'a desperate move'
item.description: American hostage Peter Kassig purportedly beheaded in new online video attributed to terror group ISIS.

item.title: Ex-soldier helped victims of war
item.description: Peter Kassig first went to the Middle East as a U.S. soldier and returned as a medical worker, feeling compelled to help victims of war.

item.title: Hagel may consider Iraq ground forces
item.description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel is suggesting he may have to consider recommendations to place ground forces in Iraq to help Iraq forces locate targets if, in fact, General Martin Dempsey, chairman of the joint chiefs makes that recommendation.

item.title: ISIS 'amputates smokers' fingers'
item.description: Killings, rapes, amputations and lashings. A catalog of ISIS abuses is gathered by the United Nations as it issues a call for the group to be brought to justice.

item.title: Recovery of MH17 wreckage starts
item.description: The recovery of wreckage in eastern Ukraine from downed Malaysia Airlines flight 17 has begun, the Dutch Safety Board announced on its website Sunday.

item.title: Ebola-infected doctor arrives in U.S.
item.description: A surgeon diagnosed with Ebola in his native Sierra Leone arrives in the United States, where he will undergo treatment at The Nebraska Medical Center in Omaha.

item.title: Grief explodes in Sierra Leone
item.description: A brave team collects the victims of a virus that is tearing Sierra Leonian villages apart.

item.title: U.S. chemical plant leak kills 4
item.description: Four workers were killed Saturday after a chemical leak at a DuPont plant in La Porte, Texas, on the eastern outskirts of Houston, plant manager Randall Clements said.

item.title: Top U.S. general assesses ISIS fight
item.description: Days after refusing to rule out recommending U.S. combat troops in Iraq, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff made an unexpected trip Saturday in the turbulent Middle Eastern nation to talk with officials there about combating ISIS, an official said.

item.title: Philae comet lander loses power
item.description: After an improbable 10-year, 310-million-mile journey to become the first ever space vehicle to make a soft landing on a comet, the Philae probe may have ended its mission prematurely.

item.title: U.S. court awards lap dancers $10M
item.description: More than 2,000 current and former exotic dancers in New York City were awarded $10 million in a class-action lawsuit they brought against their employer, Rick's Cabaret.

item.title: Report: Ferguson encounter was brief
item.description: The fatal encounter that ended with the shooting of Michael Brown by officer Darren Wilson was brief, lasting less than two minutes, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported.

item.title: Boko Haram seizes kidnap town
item.description: Boko Haram fighters sweep into three Nigerian towns including Chibok -- the scene of its mass kidnap of more than 200 schoolgirls, local residents tell CNN.

item.title: Will HK students be forced out?
item.description: Hong Kong's remaining protesters may soon be forced to clear out from occupied areas. CNN's Kristie Lu Stout reports.

item.title: Paris police hunt big cat on loose
item.description: The big cat spotted in the woods east of Paris isn't a tiger after all, French authorities said Friday, citing analysis of the beast's tracks.

item.title: Foreign sub 'entered Swedish waters'
item.description: A foreign submarine recently trespassed in Swedish territory, the military confirms -- but the identify of the vessel's nationality remains a mystery.

item.title: U.S. SEAL: We didn't expect to live
item.description: The Navy SEAL who says he killed Osama bin Laden tells CNN he did not expect to survive the mission but he's glad that 9/11 families now know what happened in bin Laden's compound.

item.title: Prince William, Kate to visit U.S.
item.description: Prince William and his wife, Catherine, will cross the pond to New York for the first time next month, paying their respects to victims at the National September 11 Memorial and Museum in lower Manhattan and catching a Brooklyn Nets game at the Barclays Center.

item.title: Mayor charged in student killings
item.description: A mayor forced from office over alleged involvement in the kidnap and murder of 43 students is formally charged by prosecutors who believe he masterminded the outrage.

item.title: 'Corpse' wakes up after 11 hours
item.description: Never underestimate the healing power of a good nap.

item.title: Putin ditches G20 after verbal jabs
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin leaves the G20 summit in Australia after a series of sharp verbal jabs from world leaders. The reason? Ukraine.

item.title: G20 agrees to boost growth
item.description: World leaders at the G20 summit have agreed to a series of measures to boost global economic growth, Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott said Sunday.

item.title: Russia 'overshadows summit'
item.description: CNNi talks to Michael Kofman of the Woodrow Wilson Center about Vladimir Putin's chilly reception at the G20 Summit.

item.title: Discovered: Funny, rude medieval doodles
item.description: My personal favorite is this. At the top of a page of angular medieval text -- full of theological extrapolations and religious devotion -- is a cartoon of a deadpan dog.

item.title: How Victorians dressed for death
item.description: Today, mourning a death in the family often means donning the most formal black outfit in one's closet for one solemn afternoon. But 150 years ago, it was a reason to stash away one's current best and purchase a whole new grief-appropriate wardrobe.

item.title: China: No more 'weird' buildings
item.description: The Chinese leadership has called for less "weird architecture" to be built in the country. Does it mean the end of unusual structures like these?

item.title: Louis Vuitton's Paris landmark
item.description: Luxury enthusiasts, rejoice: Louis Vuitton is bringing its upscale sensibilities to the art world.

item.title: The greatest beards in history
item.description: When it comes to facial hair, there are few more passionate advocates than Phil Olsen.

item.title: 10 works of art that shocked the world
item.description: As the Turner Prize turns 30 years old, we look at the formula for controversy and what the work we hate says about our society.

item.title: The most amazing train stations
item.description: Whether they're blasting over the tracks in Germany or Japan, trains offer travelers a chance to sit back and relax as they ride through some of the world's most incredible scenery.

item.title: Dylan Thomas notes found 70 years on
item.description: A notebook full of drafts of some of the poet's key works is found decades after his mother-in-law ordered it to be burnt.

item.title: Inside Ukraine's 'Corruption Museum'
item.description: CNN's Richard Quest tours the former home of ousted president Viktor Yanukovych which is now open to the public.

item.title: What does the future hold for Bitcoin?
item.description: Viewing this on a mobile device? Go here

item.title: The response that will win the Ebola war
item.description: "When the Ebola outbreak started, it was very terrifying for everybody," recalls Michael Chu'no Ike from Nsukka in Nigeria's Enugu State. "People were afraid it could be transmitted by air and started believing all sorts of rumors about how to boost their immunity."

item.title: Delicious 21st century comfort food
item.description: Environmental advocate and philanthropist Laura Turner Seydel shows us her favorite spots in Atlanta.

item.title: Twin sisters reunited on Facebook
item.description: Twin sisters Anais Bordier and Sam Futerman were separated at birth 25 years ago and reunites through social media.

item.title: Can sunblock cause fertility problems?
item.description: The cold snap that's hitting much of the country this week may leave you with a real desire to head to the beach. If you do, you may want to watch what kind of sunblock you use.

item.title: Taylor Swift takes on the world
item.description: She was a teen country music star but now she is using her talent and power to change the music industry.

item.title: Rape allegations haunt Bill Cosby
item.description: In the Internet age, claims stubbornly remain in the open.

item.title: Delicious 21st century comfort food
item.description: Environmental advocate and philanthropist Laura Turner Seydel shows us her favorite spots in Atlanta.

item.title: 'Virtual wallet' to power spending
item.description: CNN's Richard Quest explores how mobile payment solutions and biometric authentication are changing the way we pay.

item.title: Revel in Shanghai's unique buzz
item.description: Here's how to cram the best of Shanghai into your trip.

item.title: The race is on for flying cars
item.description: Affordable and easily-to-pilot flying cars are almost here -- but which will be the best?

item.title: Ukrainian battle caught on camera
item.description: Russia has denied allegations that it has sent weapons inside Ukraine. CNN's Jim Sciutto reports.

item.title: Crying for justice, clinging to hope
item.description: The parents of 43 students in Mexico are hoping against hope that their children are still alive.

item.title: 'Rich Kids of Tehran' party on
item.description: Defying ban, Instagram account captures decadent lifestyles in conservative country.

item.title: How to hack your mind
item.description: Class is in session at these nine "schools" that will help you master everyday life.

item.title: Thailand's grisly top tourist attraction
item.description: Hewn by hand from rock, Hellfire Pass symbolizes lost lives of thousands of POWs.

item.title: Unflinching look at Indonesia's past
item.description: New movie examines fallout from 1965 massacre that killed one million.

item.title: Did China steal stealth fighter design?
item.description: China shows off its new stealth fighter jet, but did it steal the design from an American company? Brian Todd reports.

item.title: The new train that redefines fast
item.description: European airlines beware: Eurostar, the high-speed train company connecting London with Brussels and Paris, has just upped its game.

item.title: Sex museums: A global guide
item.description: The subject of erotica has a way of making people uncomfortable.

item.title: S. African leaders brawl over Zuma dig
item.description: It took riot police to break up a parliament brawl in Capetown, South Africa. CNN's Diana Magnay reports.

item.title: Best-prepared country for climate change is...
item.description: Analysts are right to assess the level of national preparedness to climate change -- but well-intentioned efforts to rank countries can inadvertently sow hopelessness among those considered to be ill-prepared.

item.title: It's a '100m run while playing chess'
item.description: Ai Fukuhara's face is a picture of concentration as she crouches over the table tennis table, batting ball after ball back to her opponent.

item.title: Meet Bob, the robotic security guard
item.description: Bob is a robot that can learn using state-of-the-art artificial intelligence. CNN's Nick Glass reports.

item.title: Island paradise targets more beach-goers
item.description: With its pristine beaches, warm water and coral reefs, Seychelles has long been a must-visit destination for jet-setters from all over the world. They come from Europe, the Middle East and Asia to unwind in the sun. But not all the hosts can afford to be so relaxed.

item.title: What's inside world's most expensive watch
item.description: The most "complicated" handmade watch in the world has been sold at auction for an historic $24.4 million.

item.title: Artist creates 'living paintings'
item.description: Designer Aerosyn-Lex Mestrovic has come up with a unique style of painting that brings movement to his incredible work.

item.title: 'Rich Kids of Tehran' party on
item.description: Defying ban, Instagram account captures decadent lifestyles in conservative country.

item.title: Revel in Shanghai's unique buzz
item.description: Here's how to cram the best of Shanghai into your trip.

item.title: Holy buildings like you've never seen
item.description: Self-taught Iranian photographer gains rare access to shoot religious buildings as they've never been seen.

item.title: World's strangest sausages?
item.description: No trip around Europe is complete without sampling its oddest offal-based snacks. Then again ...

item.title: Putin puts move on China's first lady
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin slipped a shawl over the shoulders of China's first lady, Peng Liyuan.

item.title: Twin sisters reunited on Facebook
item.description: Twin sisters Anais Bordier and Sam Futerman were separated at birth 25 years ago and reunites through social media.

item.title: Artist creates 'living paintings'
item.description: Designer Aerosyn-Lex Mestrovic has come up with a unique style of painting that brings movement to his incredible work.

item.title: Scandinavia: New home of internet?
item.description: The sub-zero climes of northern Sweden are an unlikely outpost for the world's hippest tech firms, but that's where the likes of Facebook are setting up shop.

item.title: The new train that redefines fast
item.description: Eurostar's e320 will zoom you from London to Paris at 200 mph.

item.title: Prince William, Kate to visit Big Apple
item.description: Royal couple will cross the pond to New York but will Prince George make the trip?

item.title: How the comet mission helps in the search for aliens
item.description: Those searching for life beyond our planet say the Rosetta mission's comet landing marks a significant step.

item.title: Map shows barrage of asteroids
item.description: Fiery asteroids smash into Earth's atmosphere at a stunning rate.

item.title: Is Rosetta sexiest mission ever?
item.description: From the realms of science fiction to science fact, the Rosetta mission will reach its climax on Wednesday, when the mission scientists attempt their most audacious feat to date -- to put a robotic lander on a moving comet.

item.title: An apartheid you've never heard of
item.description: Myanmar refuses to recognize the Rohingya minority, and more than 100,000 have fled.

item.title: Who are the Rohingya?
item.description: CNN's Ivan Watson explains why the conflict in Myanmar is forcing the Rohingya people to flee their own country.

item.title: No place to call home
item.description: Nget Chaung, a camp for displaced people on a marginal smudge of low-lying coastland in western Myanmar, is not a place anyone would want to call home.

item.title: Race against time before batteries die
item.description: European Space Agency is back in contact with the Philae comet lander and scientists are scrambling to carry out their goals before power runs out.

item.title: Global wealth gap is 'obscene'
item.description: Leaders meeting in the land of the "fair go" must tackle inequality, says top Australian advocate.

item.title: Awkward times at G20
item.description: Barack Obama calls out China at the G20 summit in Australia, where tensions are high over Russia's role in the Ukraine crisis.

item.title: Philae sleeps
item.description: After an improbable 10-year, 310-million-mile journey to become the first ever space vehicle to make a soft landing on a comet, the Philae probe may have ended its mission prematurely.

item.title: Ebola doctor
item.description: A Sierra Leone doctor diagnosed with Ebola left the West African nation Saturday and is headed to Nebraska for treatment, U.S. officials said.

item.title: Has ISIS peaked?
item.description: Airstrikes and more assertive Iraqi and Kurdish forces are putting pressure on ISIS.

item.title: Paris: 'Beast on loose'
item.description: The big cat spotted in the woods east of Paris isn't a tiger after all, French authorities said Friday, citing analysis of the beast's tracks.

item.title: Bill Cosby
item.description: In the Internet age, claims stubbornly remain in the open.

item.title: Who runs ISIS?
item.description: Tom Foreman explains how ISIS's ruthless leader Abu Bakr Al-Baghdadi is quickly making a name for himself.

item.title: Twins reunited on Facebook
item.description: Twin sisters Anais Bordier and Sam Futerman were separated at birth 25 years ago and reunites through social media.

item.title: Surf's up ... in Alaska
item.description: Alaska's Turnagain Arm water is cold but good surfers can ride the bore for miles.

item.title: The car with a jet engine
item.description: Blast off in the 1963 Chrysler Turbine car, which has a jet engine under its hood.

item.title: Hope for Nigerian schoolgirls?
item.description: Isha Sesay explains why the Nigerian girls, once seemingly so close to release, still haven't come home.

item.title: Therapy on wheels in Sweden
item.description: Taxi Stockholm is offering free therapy sessions in the Swedish capital. CNN's Jim Boulden explains how it works.

item.title: My mother deserved to die with dignity
item.description: Dying with dignity is more than just for the person who is dying. It's for their loved ones.

item.title: To be a black cat on Halloween
item.description: From ancient superstitions to modern photography, black cats face their share of unique issues -- especially this time of year.

item.title: Perspective-defying photos
item.description: It all started when she kissed the Great Sphinx of Giza.

item.title: Capturing a solar eclipse
item.description: If there's one thing we've learned about the CNN iReport community, it's that you all love to capture celestial events.

item.title: I'm a feminist, and I converted to Islam
item.description: I am a Muslim, but I wasn't always. I converted to Islam in November 2001, two months after 9/11.

item.title: China's new 'stealth' fighter
item.description: Zhuhai's Air Show has always been a venue for surprises, usually first-time showings of advanced Chinese military hardware.

item.title: Watershed moment for climate politics
item.description: For the world's two largest economies -- and largest emitters of greenhouse gas -- to announce a sustained commitment to reducing carbon emissions by almost a third by the year 2030 is a watershed moment for climate politics on so many fronts.

item.title: Is a China-Japan thaw likely?
item.description: OK, so Chinese President Xi Jinping and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's brief summit featured all the enthusiasm of two unhappy schoolboys forced to make up after a schoolyard dust-up.

item.title: China's 55 ethnic minorities
item.description: For a year, journalist and author David Eimer traveled the edges of China exploring a side of the country that obliterates expectations.

item.title: Michelin's 'undisputed leader' in cuisine
item.description: Tokyoites may brag about having the most Michelin stars in the world, but Hong Kongers can actually eat in theirs without breaking the bank.

item.title: Beating smog in style
item.description: High fashion isn't often inspired by environmental hazards, but as air pollution levels soared in Beijing on Tuesday, models at China Fashion Week walked the runway wearing designer respiratory face masks.

item.title: Taking 'selfies' with a drone
item.description: What comes in a white cardboard box, weighs little more than a kilogram and can be purchased in a few clicks from Amazon?
